publisher.publisher-name: The New Testament Society of South Africa / Die Nuwe-Testamentiese Werkgemeenskap van Suid-Afrika

title-group.article-title: THE EXTERIORITY OF BIBLICAL MEANING AND THE PLENTITUDE OF DESIRE: AN EXPLORATION OF DELEUZE'S NON-METAPHYSICAL HERMENEUTICS OF KAFKA

permissions.copyright-statement: COPYRIGHT © 2009 THE NEW TESTAMENT SOCIETY OF SOUTH AFRICA (NTSSA)

abstract.p: Hermeneutical theory remains rooted in a metaphysics of the "interiority of meaning". For example, Ricoeur transposed Freud's metaphysics of interior libidinal meaning into a literary theory of interpretation. The corollary to Freud's metaphysics of interiorized meaning is "desire as lack". Deleuze and Guattari's attack on Freud's theory of historical-libidinal drives formed the basis of their explication of the "rhizomatic" exteriority of meaning, which they develop, in literary terms, in their book, Kafka: Toward a Minor Literature. In their view, Kafka's novels model a style of writing that disavows interior meaning. They also oppose the primacy of Freud's concept of desire-as-lack with that of desire-as-plenitude. This paper will discuss a mode of biblical interpretation based on the twin concepts of exteriority of meaning and desire-as-plentitude, according to four interpretive stategies: 1) rediscover one's hyperdifferentiated life; 2) think politically; 3) seek out interstitial spaces; 4) change one's point of entry.

p.mixed-citation: John Toews, "the creation of meaning is impersonal, operating "behind the backs" of language users whose linguistic actions can merely exemplify the rules and procedures of languages they inhabit but do not control" (1987, 882).
Réda Bensmaïa, "Introduction," in Deleuze, Guattari, 1986 [1975], xviii.
Réda Bensmaïa, "Introduction," in Deleuze and Guattari 1986 [1975], xxvii.
